articles.content: Common sense is a simple and non-self-conscious use of logic.
articles.attribution:
Ayn Rand, question period following the lecture
The Philosophy of Objectivism lecture series, Lecture 11

articles.content: That which today is called “common sense” is the remnant of an Aristotelian influence.
articles.attribution:
“For the New Intellectual,”
For the New Intellectual, 41

articles.content:
Americans are the most reality-oriented people on earth.  Their outstanding
characteristic is the childhood form of reasoning: common sense.  It is their
only protection.  But common sense is not enough where theoretical knowledge is
required: it can make simple, concrete-bound connections—it cannot integrate
complex issues, or deal with wide abstractions, or forecast the future.
articles.attribution:
“Don’t Let It Go,”
Philosophy: Who Needs It, 211
